abstract.p: Briarcliff Manor Conservation Advisory Council chairman Steven Kavee letter disputes August 15 letter on wind energy versus nuclear power

block.p: Briarcliff Manor is currently planning to join its Westchester neighbors in buying wind-generated electricity for municipal use. We also hope to encourage homeowners to buy this clean and renewable energy source.

The modest (and regularly decreasing) premium for wind energy pays off in the social and economic benefits that the writer of an Aug. 15 letter calculates as deficits on his environmental balance sheet.

Briarcliff Manor is currently planning to join its Westchester neighbors in buying wind-generated electricity for municipal use. We also hope to encourage homeowners to buy this clean and renewable energy source.

The modest (and regularly decreasing) premium for wind energy pays off in the social and economic benefits that the writer of an Aug. 15 letter calculates as deficits on his environmental balance sheet.

Proponents of nuclear energy fail to account for the billions of dollars in decommissioning costs and the still unsolved problem of storage of tons of nuclear waste for the thousands of years it remains lethal. And this does not even take into account the ever-present danger of nuclear disaster through accident, negligence or terrorist attack.

The 300,000 acres of windmills required to replace Indian Point's output (according to the conservative Manhattan Institute's estimate) would be passively located on farms, mountaintops and other large parcels, or even in the Atlantic Ocean. The result would preserve open space and provide much-needed financial support for local agriculture, protecting local food production and the clean air to sustain it.
Steven Kavee Chairman, Briarcliff Manor Conservation Advisory Council Briarcliff
